summary.sub_title: Launch of the France Very High Speed Broadband Plan (2013)

part1_p1: In 2007, France began equipping its network with fibre optics. Unlike ADSL, which uses copper lines, fibre optics use glass or plastic cables to transmit data in the form of light. This technology offers several advantages:

part1_list.list1: Much faster transfer speeds, around 200 Mb/s at the time, far higher than ADSL.
part1_list.list2: Virtually no loss of speed due to distance.
part1_list.list3: Enhanced connection stability, less affected by environmental interference.

part1_p2: When first introduced, fibre optics were mainly deployed in the most urbanised areas, where deployment costs were lower.
part2_title: Launch of the France Very High Speed Broadband Plan (2013)
part2_p1: In 2013, the France Very High Speed Broadband Plan was launched. The plan aims to build a fibre optic network to connect subscribers across the country by the end of 2022. The initiative has two objectives:

part2_list.list1: to reduce the digital divide between regions
part2_list.list2: to guarantee very high-speed internet access (above 30 Mb/s) for all citizens, whether they live in urban or rural areas.

part2_p2: The new fibre optic network is intended to gradually replace the existing copper network (RTC/ADSL) to become the sole fixed-line internet access network covering the whole of France.
part3_p1: What is the situation today? Has the plan progressed as expected?
part3_p2: By the end of 2023, 84% of the rollout had been completed, compared to the initial target of full coverage by 2022. ARCEP fined Orange for the delay in extending coverage to less densely populated areas.
part3_p3: Given the slowdown in deployment, it is now estimated that the objective of full coverage by 2025 will not be met.
part3_p4: Nevertheless, fibre continues to expand: in January 2025, 39.9 million premises were eligible, representing 91% of French territory, according to ARCEP. Estimates indicate that this percentage could reach 100% by the end of 2025, although this seems uncertain: 4.6 million premises still need to be connected, many of which are in complex or low-density areas.

item.comment: Strong growth in Very High Speed Broadband access
